threads.author: anachrocomputer
threads.content: Looks like one mode is JTAG (TDO/TMS) and the other mode is SWD (SWDIO). But SWDIO goes to both pin 6 and pin 3 of the switch

threads.author: hasanthesyrian_
threads.content: the switch selects between jtag/spi and swd/i2c

threads.author: hasanthesyrian_
threads.content:
this is what they said in my github issue but i still dont get it
```
The "mode switch" on the board that switches between jtag/spi and i2c/swd basically connects the poci/tdo pin to the pico/tdi pin with a 330 ohm resistor.
This is because both i2c and swd have a bidirectional data pin, so we need to be able to both read and write to it, but the FT2232H does not really support that.

If you mean switching between spi and jtag and i2c and swd for the different tools - that's all taken care of by the software tools. The FTx232H family all support MPSSE, which is their way of doing high throughput I/O. That's what PyFtdi, flashrom, openocd, and others all use to make the ft2232h speak their protocol.
```

threads.author: hasanthesyrian_
threads.content:
this is what they said in my github issue but i still dont get it
```
The "mode switch" on the board that switches between jtag/spi and i2c/swd basically connects the poci/tdo pin to the pico/tdi pin with a 330 ohm resistor.
This is because both i2c and swd have a bidirectional data pin, so we need to be able to both read and write to it, but the FT2232H does not really support that.

If you mean switching between spi and jtag and i2c and swd for the different tools - that's all taken care of by the software tools. The FTx232H family all support MPSSE, which is their way of doing high throughput I/O. That's what PyFtdi, flashrom, openocd, and others all use to make the ft2232h speak their protocol.
```

threads.author: cooperg2001

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: It should be a `Silkscreen clipped by silkscreen` or `Silkscreens overlap` or similar but instead its  `Silkscreen clipped by solder mask`

threads.author: analogy
threads.content: I would definitely take a second look at the thickness of the trace coming off the VBus pin - that's a current-carrying trace

threads.author: hasnat4763
threads.content: It is not more than 500mA ig

threads.author: fisheiyy
threads.content: still a 0.15 or 0.2mm trace is not enough for that imo

threads.author: hasnat4763
threads.content: I've been using that width always

threads.author: hasnat4763
threads.content: lol

threads.author: fisheiyy
threads.content: you should increase it to at least 0.35mm

threads.author: hasnat4763
threads.content: ok

threads.author: analogy
threads.content: Wider traces are also better for manufacturing yield - if your PCB has generous tolerances you'll generally find that you end up with a few extra boards in the package when it shows up. These prototype manufacturers make more boards than you order in case a few come out duds, then they just give you all of the ones that pass inspection cause otherwise they're just gonna throw em away. So if your tolerances are generous, you get more bonus boards.
